MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001803
Special Investigation Intake Date: September 25, 2024
License #: CI820201008
Licensee Group Organization: Spectrum Juvenile Justice Services
Licensee Designee: Derrick McCree
Chief Administrator: Tia Cobb
Agency Name: CALUMET CENTER
Agency Address: 330 GLENDALE ST
HIGHLAND PARK, MI 48203-3277
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 08/24/2025
Capacity: 90
II. METHODOLOGY

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or
Section shelter care institutions; initial treatment plan
Description (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
initial treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days of
admission.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that there are no treatment plans for youth.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/27/24.
Complainant reported she doesn’t think there have been any
treatment plans completed for Youth A because Clinical Case
Manager (CCM) has not been in contact with her to discuss any
treatment plans and she has never received a copy of a treatment
plan. Complainant reported when her daughter emailed CCM
about the treatment plan, CCM responded with a generic
statement about Youth A having a treatment team who all work
together to develop the treatment plan.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth A was very difficult to engage with. He was very withdrawn
and had a flat affect. Youth A requested to leave the conversation
before being asked any questions about his treatment plan.
Clinical Case Manager (CCM) was interviewed face to face at
the facility on 9/30/24. CCM reported Youth A has an initial
treatment plan. CCM reported Youth A refuses to participate in or
sign his treatment plans on most occasions. CCM reported she
continues to try to engage Youth A in treatment planning, but it’s
mostly unsuccessful.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth A’s initial treatment plan dated 1/26/24-2/24/24 was
completed and signed by CCM.
• Write up from Youth A’s JJ Worker dated 9/26/24 states he
was provided an initial treatment plan by the facility dated
3/25/24.
• Program Statement states a treatment planning conference
will be held within 30 calendar days after admission to the
facility. Process will assess a youth’s treatment needs,
goals, risk/security level, and what services will be offered
to address identified needs/goals. It also notes an initial
treatment plan will be completed within the timeframes
specified by ACT 116, 1974, as amended, and be provided
to the referring source.
• Clinical Case Manager (CCM) does not have any
disciplinary records in her employee file. CCM completed
clinical training, which included training on completion and
2

processes for treatment plans, on 1/9/24, 1/23/24, 2/27/24,
3/19/24, 4/16/24, 4/23/24, 5/24/24, 5/21/24, 6/4/24, 6/11/24
and 6/18/24.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, the initial treatment plan was
completed within 30 days and was signed/dated by the case
manager.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Program Statement notes the facility includes the family in the
development of updated treatment plans. If Youth A’s mother is
being excluded from these meetings for a particular reason (such
as a requirement or direction by the Office of Family/Child
Advocate), please ensure there is documentation noting this in
Youth A’s file to ensure you are meeting the requirements of the
facility program statement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or
Section shelter care institutions; updated treatment plan
Description (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the initial treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that there are no treatment plans for youth.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/27/24.
Complainant reported she doesn’t think there have been any
treatment plans completed for Youth A because Clinical Case
Manager (CCM) has not been in contact with her to discuss any
treatment plans and she has never received a copy of a treatment
plan. Complainant reported when her daughter emailed CCM
about the treatment plan, CCM responded with a generic
statement about Youth A having a treatment team who all work
together to develop the treatment plan.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth A was very difficult to engage with. He was very withdrawn
and had a flat affect. Youth A requested to leave the conversation
before being asked any questions about his treatment plan.
Clinical Case Manager (CCM) was interviewed face to face at
the facility on 9/30/24. CCM reported Youth A has updated
treatment plans. CCM reported Youth A refuses to participate in or
sign his treatment plans on most occasions. CCM reported she
3

continues to try to engage Youth A in treatment planning, but it’s
mostly unsuccessful.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth A had updated treatment plans dated 2/25/24-
5/24/24 and 5/25/24-8/22/24, which were completed and
signed by CCM.
• Write up from Youth A’s JJ Worker dated 9/26/24 states he
was provided updated treatment plans by the facility dated
5/24/24 and 8/22/24.
• Program Statement states updated treatment plans will be
completed within the timeframes specified by ACT 116,
1974, as amended, and be provided to the referring source.
• Clinical Case Manager (CCM) does not have any
disciplinary records in her employee file. CCM completed
clinical training, which included training on completion and
processes for treatment plans, on 1/9/24, 1/23/24, 2/27/24,
3/19/24, 4/16/24, 4/23/24, 5/24/24, 5/21/24, 6/4/24, 6/11/24
and 6/18/24.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, the updated treatment plans were
completed timely and were signed/dated by the case manager.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On Friday, via a Zoom meeting, Youth A looked "drugged out and
doped up." Youth A suffers from mental illness and is not taking
his meds.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/27/24.
Complainant reported there was a Zoom meeting on 9/20/24 and
Youth A looked “like a crackhead”, which she assessed based on
his eyes and body language. Complainant reported Youth A
looked “zoned out” and “in a daze”. Complainant reported she and
her daughter asked if Youth A was okay, but Youth A wouldn’t
respond or talk on the call. Complainant reported she has never
4

seen him look like that before. Complainant admitted Youth A
hasn’t wanted to complete phone calls, video calls, or in person
visits with her since he has been at the facility (end of January
2024), so she has not seen him in a while.
Complainant reported Youth A is diagnosed with Autism, an
Intellectual Disability Disorder, Bipolar, and a Mood Disorder.
Complainant reported she is supposed to receive weekly progress
reports and all the ones she has received states Youth A is
refusing to take his medication. Complainant reported she isn’t
sure how long Youth A has been prescribed medications, and she
did not provide consent for him to be prescribed medications.
Complainant reported some of his medications have remained the
same since before he entered the facility, but some have
changed, and she doesn’t know why. Complainant reported since
Youth A won’t have contact with her, she isn’t sure why Youth A is
refusing the medications. Complainant is concerned the facility
isn’t doing enough to ensure Youth A’s mental health and
medication needs are met.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth A was very difficult to engage with. He was very withdrawn,
quiet, and had a very flat affect. He expressed he didn’t want to
talk but agreed to answer a few questions. Youth A reported he
doesn’t want to take his medications. Youth A reported he couldn’t
remember if anyone has talked to him about his medications.
Clinical Case Manager (CCM) was interviewed face to face at
the facility on 9/30/24. CCM reported on 9/20/24, Youth A was
supposed to have an in-person visit with his sister, but at the last
minute, he refused to complete the visit. As a compromise, Youth
A agreed to complete a Zoom meeting to complete a visit with his
sister. However, when Youth A got on the Zoom meeting, his
mother as well as his sister were present. CCM reported Youth A
has been very clear about not wanting to have any contact with
his mother since being at the facility, and CCM reported his
mother and sister are aware of his feelings. CCM reported when
Youth A saw his mother was on the Zoom meeting, he became
visibly uncomfortable with the situation because he never agreed
to meet with her or speak with her, and no one told them his
mother would be present. CCM reported at one point during the
call, Youth A’s mother took the phone and was on camera
screaming about Youth A looking “drugged up”. CCM reported
Youth A wouldn’t speak to his mother or sister because of how
uncomfortable he was with the situation. Eventually, Youth A
asked CCM if he had to stay in the visit, and CCM told him he
5

didn’t have to stay, so Youth A chose to end the visit early. CCM
reported Youth A typically presents as non-talkative, with a flat
affect on a normal basis, and he didn’t look or act any different
during this call except for being clearly uncomfortable with the
situation with his mother.
CCM reported in February, Youth A began showing some signs of
possible psychosis, so he was taken for psychiatric treatment.
CCM reported during his treatment, he was prescribed
medications. CCM reported Youth A is offered his medications
every day during medication passing time, but he has continued to
refuse medications. CCM reported they cannot force him to take
his medications, and he has the right to refuse medications. CCM
reported Youth A has not given a consistent or clear reason for
not wanting to take his medications. CCM reported at one point
Youth A stated he didn’t need medications, but mostly Youth A
“zones out” and says he doesn’t want to talk about the reasons.
CCM reported Youth A’s JJ Worker is working on scheduling
Youth A for a neuropsychological evaluation.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Email from Youth A’s JJ Worker dated 9/26/24 states Youth
A was taken to the hospital in March 2024 for mental health
concerns. Youth A was there for a few days and released.
Since his release, Youth A has refused to comply with his
medications. Youth A’s JJ Worker is in the process of trying
to schedule a neuropsychological assessment.
• Reviewed MiSACWIS social work contacts from 8/19/24-
9/26/24. Weekly emails from CCM to Youth A’s JJ Worker
note Youth A is noncompliant with medications.
• Medication Logs for Youth A from 7/1/24-9/30/24 note
Youth A refused all prescribed medications for the entire
time.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, the facility is offering Youth A his
medication, but Youth A is refusing to comply.
In addition, there is nothing to support Youth A is being “drugged”.
Youth A has refused to take all his medications. In Youth A’s face
to face interview with this consultant, Youth A was quiet,
withdrawn, and had a flat affect. Youth A has expressed he does
not want to have contact with his mother, but his mother chose to
attend the Zoom call without his permission. According to CCM,
6

Youth A was physically uncomfortable with the situation, and it
showed in his body language.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123 Education
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has not been to school since February.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/27/24.
Complainant reported Youth A is enrolled in Covenant Schools,
but since Youth A won’t speak to her, she’s not sure why he isn’t
going to school. Complainant is concerned the facility isn’t doing
enough to ensure Youth A’s educational needs are met.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 9/30/24.
Youth A was very difficult to engage with. Youth A, at first,
reported he didn’t want to go to school. However, then he reported
he wanted to attend school, but if someone talked to him about it,
he doesn’t know if he would go.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 9/30/24. CA reported Youth A was enrolled in
Covenant Schools and has been enrolled since a couple days
after arriving at the facility. CA reported school is held in a
classroom on Youth A’s pod. To attend school, Youth A must exit
his bedroom, walk across the pod, and enter the door for the
school. CA reported they cannot physically force any youth to
attend school, so Youth A must choose to attend, which he has
refused to do.
Clinical Case Manager (CCM) was interviewed face to face at
the facility on 9/30/24. CCM reported Youth A is enrolled in
school, which occurs on the pod in which Youth A resides. CCM
reported education for each youth at the facility is individualized.
CCM reported it’s mostly online-based education, but there is a
teacher instructing the class as well as Special Education
teachers circulating to assist youth as needed. CCM reported
every morning, all youth are woken up, told it’s time to get ready,
provided with breakfast, and then provided the opportunity to
attend school. CCM reported Youth A cannot be physically forced
to do his schooling, and he has refused to attend consistently.
7

CCM reported at the beginning of the summer, Youth A would
agree to attend school occasionally, but he wouldn’t complete any
schoolwork or participate in class.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Resident Education Policy states all youth will be enrolled
in an education program not later than 5 days after
admission, and continuously thereafter throughout the
duration of their stay.
• Write up from Youth A’s JJ worker dated 9/26/24 states
Youth A is enrolled in Covenant House Academy, which is
computer-based course work. Youth A has refused to
participate in educational services, which has been
documented in weekly updates dating back to April 2024.
• Reviewed MiSACWIS social work contacts from 8/19/24-
9/26/24. Weekly emails from CCM to Youth A’s JJ Worker
note Youth A is refusing to participate in educational
programming.
• MiSACWIS social work contact written by Youth A’s JJ
Worker documents an email written by Principal to Youth
A’s mother on 8/26/24. Principal states Youth A has been
uncooperative with school. Principal notes they make
efforts to get work to him, but Youth A needs to attend
school for them to assist him. Principal notes they will
continue to ensure services are offered to Youth A, but
Youth A must be willing to speak with school staff.
• Email from Principal dated 10/4/24 states Youth A’s special
education provider and teachers make attempts to engage
Youth A daily. Unfortunately, Youth A typically refuses and
doesn’t complete work.
• Functional Behavioral Assessment for Youth A dated
9/8/24 notes when teachers and staff make attempts to
interact or engage with Youth A directly, Youth A becomes
agitated, irritated, and irrational. He is combative and
destructive. It also states Youth A is in self-isolation
throughout the school day. Although he is encouraged to
join the classroom or participate in classroom activities, he
declines. Youth A is provided daily paper instructions, but
he fails to complete any assignments and refuses any
assistance when asked.
8

• Covenant Schools Detroit Official Transcript for Youth A
dated 10/4/24 states Youth A was enrolled in school on
1/26/24 and continues to be enrolled in school.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, Youth A was enrolled in school on
the date he was admitted to the facility and continues to be
enrolled in school.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
October 7, 2024
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 10, 2024
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager

sir_summary.summary: A complaint alleged that a youth at the Calumet Center lacked treatment plans, appeared 'drugged' and was not taking medication, and was not attending school. The investigation found the facility in compliance: initial and updated treatment plans were documented and timely, the youth was offered but refused all medication, and he was enrolled but refused to attend school. The report attributes the issues primarily to the youth's refusal to participate in services and notes a family conflict contributed to the perception of him being 'drugged.' Ultimately, the facility was found not culpable for the alleged violations.
